author: frank4frank007
title: Dripada: Nigeria’s Cardano Hub
description: Nigeria despite being on the top list of cryptocurrency users globally are still yet to get familiar with Cardano and it’s unique EUTXO mechanism that is supreme to other EVM based blockchains.

f6_assessments.q0:
Partnering with WADA a well-known Cardano Hub that already has a thriving community within Nigeria seems to be a logical step rather than trying to bootstrap yourself from the ground up. 
Of the top, there are a couple of risks that could prevent you from delivering the project successfully, like not being able to find a partnership with projects that are interested in offering their tokens as incentives to your community, and how would you overcome that?
what age groups are you looking to target with this grassroots initiative?  It's a bit challenging to see how Amaka Asouzu can pull this off with no prior knowledge of how Cardano as both a tech and community operate.
f6_assessments.q1: Some links to the success of Amaka Asouzu's previous work should have been made available this can be used as a reference to measure how successful this project will be. The amount asked is reasonable, however, the cost breakdown seems vague. For example Website Redesign - $2500, Social Media Manager - $1500 USD, and Initial Awareness Campaign / Contest - $2000 USD. Despite listing these amounts it's unclear if it would be a single individual or a team that will carry out these tasks. Looking at the Telegram channel there are no pieces of information already posted that members can start to interact with things like what is Blockchain, how is Cardano different from most other blockchains in terms of how it's constructed, and how to acquire some Ada.
f6_assessments.q2: Amaka Asouzu being an experienced seasoned blogger should have provided the community with other KPIs and metrics other than the number of attendees being used as a key milestone. KPIs like youtube videos, increased number of Telegram active users participating in the learning process, and Twitter AMA's that Q&As can be asked by the community.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal's problem statement, I believe, is closely related to the challenge. However, without returning to Catalyst, the team fails to provide information on how their solution would scale up to future obstacles, such as a shortage of funds. The proposal aims to enhance the adoption of the Cardano Blockchain and raise awareness of Cardano in one of the top nations in the world with one of the highest percentages of cryptocurrency users (Nigeria).

The team seeks to organize periodic incentivized contests, giveaways, and Cardano meetups. These meetups, giveaways, and contests will increase the number of new Africa-based users being onboarded onto Cardano (wallets, platform sign-ups), increase the number of Africa-based developers on Cardano's blockchain, and also increase the volume of transactions being performed on the blockchain in Nigeria. 

If funded, I would recommend that the team partner up with other organizations and companies in Nigeria so as to reach a wider audience, gain extra funding, and become self-reliant so they won't need to return to Catalyst for additional funds.
f6_assessments.q1:
Given the experience provided, I cannot confirm whether the proposal will be carried out successfully or not. Not enough information has been provided to measure the experience and expertise of the team, as I believe that the expertise of the single proposer is not broad enough to cover all relevant areas of the proposal. The website provided doesn't provide enough information on the proposal and should be updated as stated. I would recommend updating the proposer's LinkedIn profile to have more relevant information. 
Other team members are not mentioned, aside from the contraction of freelance developers. Who handles the creation and airdropping of the Proof of Attendance NFTs? Though a budget breakdown is provided, a detailed timeline for execution is not available.
f6_assessments.q2: The information provided is not sufficient to fully audit the progress and success of the proposal. The roadmap provided in the proposal does not include any timelines for project achievement. Only one KPI is stated, and that is the number of users in the community and how engaged they are. How do you track how engaged the users are? Also, how does the proposer intend to inform the Catalyst community of the progress of the proposal? For example, through monthly or weekly reports on contests, giveaways, etc. being sent to the Catalyst community.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal identifies two parts of the challenge and addresses them head on: growing the number of users, and having a local impact.

The proposal describes a hands-on, grass-roots approach to onboarding new users. This kind of personal outreach in local communities is the approach that has been identified as the most effective in Africa. 

Growing local communities where people teach each other about Cardano and blockchain, in general, is a very effective method and this proposal takes that approach.
f6_assessments.q1:
The plan is very thin. Apart from an overall goal of hosting a meetup with 300 people, there is not much to assess. 

The proposal does not show any history of local organizing or connection to an established community that could be mobilized. 

The proposer's LinkedIn profile was unaccessible and the the Twitter profile nearly empty. It is not possible to assess the experience of the proposer.

The homepage of the website says "The goal isn't to build a community. The goal is to build your business with our community through a Creative method of engagement." This does not align with the challenge, or the stated goal of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposal describes tracking the number of new users and their engagement. There is no description of how those numbers will be tracked. For example, will there be surveys, will there be follow-ups after the meetups? What constitutes engagement. 

There are no objective metrics or timelines listed. It will be very difficult to audit the progress of this project. 

The ultimate goal of a meetup with 300 people is measurable. However, success here does not necessarily demonstrate adoption of Cardano as measured by engaged users.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal presents a problem that addresses the challenge. Indeed in Africa, Nigeria is well known for cryptocurrency and blockchain technology participation but there is less knowledge and adoption of Cardano. This proposal seeks to establish a hub that will help Nigerians participate in activities and interaction to learn and earn. I like the idea about learning and earning since it will motivate participation. This proposal if well educated will lead to awareness and massive participationa and adoption of Cardano and ADA as a cryptocurrency of choice among participants. This proposal only lists lack of funds as risks or challenges but i think there should be more, like awareness creation, multilingual issues etc.
f6_assessments.q1:
This proposal is great but for now it is only an individual idea but i think building it around a team will communicate much feasibility. Link to relevant skills and websites are given which is a plus. I think the plan is not well developed. For instance there are no timelines to measure progress. It does not also state how the hub is going to create awareness and educate participants about Cardano but only talks about contests among participants. The budget should be more elaborate to help auditing. The budget is ok since it is going to be a learn and earn project. I don't also see specific resources for execution of the contest and awareness creation. 
These are reasons for my score
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal does not present any roadmap with timelines that are measurable. There are no milestone for auditability and the proposer does not also present a step by step key performance indicators to measure progress. The only thing presented is that progress will be measured according to participation but there is no specific target of people the proposal want to reach. I think this idea is amazing but must be presented well.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is an impressive attempt to establish a community hub in Nigeria to educate and promote increased adoption of Cardano via meetups and learn to earn initiatives. Although the concept has the potential to have a substantial impact on Cardano's expansion in Africa, there is not enough information to make an outstanding impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
Although the author claims that this project will be contracted out to developers, he didn't specify which contractors he would use so that we could assess their suitability for the task and how well they would be able to complete it. A website for the organization was provided by the author, however it contains little information. That is, in my opinion, why he stated that developers who would be outsourced would update and rebrand it. Lack of funding was cited by the project's proposer as a potential risk that could impede the project's successful implementation. Given this, it is difficult for me to believe that, once the project has received funding, there won't be any significant risks. To me, the proposer should have done more study.
The goal does not appear to be achievable because the proposal did not fully explain how the idea will be implemented. 
Furthermore, the budget's breakdown is unclear. Despite the fact that this project has the potential spread awareness and inform the general public about Cardano, I cannot say with certainty that it is viable.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPI given and the information provided are not adequate to audit the project's progress. The extensive study required to make this concept excellent is missing. The likelihood of executing and evaluating this concept is extremely low because there are no clearly defined milestones to outline the plan.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is aligned with the objectives of the challenge. It talks about creating a community hub called Dripada, with the aim of fostering the adoption of Cardano in Nigeria through meet-ups and organizing a token-sponsored contest, which will get the user engaged and committed to learning more about Cardano while still earning.
This is a good initiative, however the proposal is very brief, the proposer also fails to elaborate on how he will tackle any setbacks should they arise. This could be a really big project and I'm not convinced that the experience of just one person is enough. Should this proposal be funded, emphasis should be made on recruiting more team members to help enhance the success of this project.
f6_assessments.q1:
The roadmap of this project is well stated but very brief. It lacks detailed timelines and specific dates to help track its progress. The proposer should have emphasized more on when each task would be taken and who would be handling it. 
The budget also lacks details as the rest of this proposal. The figures looks feasible but should however be verified by an expert with experience in this field. This project really has the potential of having a great impact on the Cardano community, but the proposer failed to present a detailed roadmap and a well-explained budget to help garner confidence in the successful establishment of such a project. This is also a one person project, and the proposer fails to establish that he has extensive experience, and it's even familiar with our blockchain.
I believe the dedication of a little more time to the refinement of this proposal would really go a long way to help in the future.
f6_assessments.q2: There is no information here to ensure easy auditability. No KPI's are stated to help measure the success of the project. No timelines for completion of work are listed. No plan on how the team plans to report to the community. The budget looks vague and the plan needs more work. There is little information to help deem this proposal auditable.

f6_assessments.q0: Countries in Africa have always been early adopters when it comes to financial technology. Despite the common idea that Africa is lagging in technological innovation, the continent is home to many forward thinking start-ups and tech solutions. When it comes to cryptocurrencies, the uptake hasn't been quite as enthusiastic. However, despite some regulatory setbacks exchanges like Luno have grown year on year. Eventhough Nigeria is one of the top list cryptocurrency users yet it has to get familiar with cardano . Dripada is a cardano focused on community that play a great role in adoption of Cardano. This proposal effectively addresses the challenge and I agree with the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has detailed plan including social channel setups, dripada website setups, website redesign and rebrand , catalyst proposal and dripada cardano meetup where attendees will be air dropped proof of attendees NFTs. The budget is outlined clearly and broken down into idenfiable items. It is reasonable to achieve set goals. The people working with the proposal has contract developers to refresh and rebrand entire website and adding new components to host, track and drsburse giveaways rewards. The proposer offers a realistic timetable to complete the work and provides a sensible and conductible plan for implementation that shows not only what is being done but also how. Given experiences and plan presented it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: The project progress can be tracked by number of user in community and how engaging they are. The budget is brokendown clearly and is acceptable. The plan describes the resources necessary to implement the proposal and clearly explains technical aspects like architecture, language and technologies if they are crucial for implementation. The proposer has considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation. The team working with the proposal has a good experience in it. The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal presents a great idea in line with the challenge goals. Creating a hub for promoting Cardano’s solutions in a top cryptocurrency user country as Nigeria, not only through meetups and media content, but with practical use and learn to earn programs seems a great opportunity to increase the adoption of Cardano in a crucial African cryptocurrency center. If fully developed, the project could become periodical, joining future Funds to expand and create a promising hub for the Cardano Community in Nigeria. However, despite exposing a very good idea, it seems to me that the proposal lacks a structured plan for the development of the project, as I will explain on the next sections.
f6_assessments.q1: In the team members section there is a brief summary of the proposer experience alongside with a Linkedin link, which is good for background information, but no other team member or participant is mentioned. The proposal offers links to a website, a twitter account and a telegram group, but they help very little in terms of feasibility since they seem recently created and barely expose any relevant information of the project’s goals and structure. Additionally, there is no timeline for the proposed plan and also there isn’t even a draft or preliminary information on the structure or plan of the Contest and Meetup mentioned in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: As mentioned in the proposal, the hub development can be tracked easily by tracking the number of active members in the community, but there isn’t an indication of how this will be publicly shared. The proposal would greatly benefit if any mentions of online sheets, drives, closing reports, or any tool planned for this objective were made. Also, many other metrics regarding engagement could be thought out and enrich the proposal. Finally, the proposal aims for a Cardano Meetup with over 3000 members in attendance, but to me the proposal is much more a great idea without a structured plan or draft to sustain the expected success.

f6_assessments.q0:
DripADA should entail a demand assessment report on why Project Catalyst should support the development of a Cardano community in Nigeria. A possible solution to this, would be to provide the necessary support documentation in terms of links and reports to the recent trend of employment in Nigeria by age category reported by the Nigerian National Bureau of Statistics and the news media.
Below are a couple of links to the report and website of those organization I highlighted above. 
https://www.nigerianstat.gov.ng/
https://businessday.ng/business-economy/article/nigeria-unemployment-hit-35-in-2021-agusto-co/#:~:text=Nigeria's%20unemployment%20rate%20rose%20to,rating%20agency%2C%20Agusto%20%26%20Co.
Due to the fact that the problem statement is poorly articulated by not addressing a real challenge in the Nigerian context, a priority judgement cannot be ascribed. A technology business incubator structure would be a better approach to address this issue and propose a well-articulated response to the challenge the project is listed in.
The link below is a sample guide developed by the World Bank for entrepreneurs and organizations interested in the development of a technology business incubator. 
https://documents1.worldbank.org/curated/en/206371562159383864/pdf/BIM-Module-3B-Planning-an-Incubator-Part-2.pdf
The impact proposition falls short of the required expectations in terms of how it will solve the category challenge – Grow Africa, Grow Cardano. This should be resolved by a new proposition and submission in Fund10. 
If the new proposed submission is well thought out and adopts the technology business incubator approach as earlier suggested, then there is a great opportunity that this idea will address future challenges with regards to skill development for the blockchain ecosystem and the Project Catalyst community. Technology business incubators are great catalyst in socio – economic development of talents and skills on the African continent.
f6_assessments.q1:
The fact that DripADA is solely presented by a single person, shows the lack of experience in terms of the required human and financial resources needed to successfully implement this idea. A probable solution to this would be to research the structure and organization of the Technology Business Incubator model. Also required is the recruitment of other professionals who have some experience in writing business plans for such incubators or are skilled at the organization and implementation of hackathons and other technology related student/community activities.
This newly proposed research should also extend to the current remuneration packages given to employees working at an incubator in the country. This will be of tremendous help in restructuring a new budget for submission to be made by the launch of Fund10.
Also, to point out that the impact statements are poorly articulated as the proposed solution does not show future growth potential that will scale the adoption of Cardano activities in Nigeria or Africa in greater context. This is also seen in the proposed risk and mitigation measures of the idea.
The idea timeline and milestones should also be reappraised beyond the impact of social media promotional activities to include other onsite and offline related community engagements that will foster the development of local talents in the country. A new timeline should also reflect the acquisition and location reconstruction or design for a community hub that will aid the delivery of talent development activities.
The budget as proposed hasn’t considered the purchase of technical software and hardware packages needed to effectively engage its community. Also missing from the budget are cost allocation items for activities related to the facilitation of training programs and their instructors, which is required by every community that builds talents.
Another item that wasn’t in the budget is the purchase and service fees for the provision of internet facilities should a hub location be decided upon. This is also an essential item needed by the hub management and the community members to effectively interact with the Project Catalyst global community,
Power generation and supply remains a key challenge in Nigeria. This facility is required for inclusion in a new budget. Its provision will relieve issues of intermittent power supply in Nigeria. It is also an essential piece to the everyday operation of the hub.
These missed items I listed above, should be included in the new manifesto and the proposer should re-apply in Fund 10.
f6_assessments.q2:
As a result, that this proposal has missed its mark on several evaluation points, the final consideration points on auditability generally will go along with my earlier assessments of re-appraising the whole submission. 
More work needs to be done with regards to the whole project including the milestones and the key performance indicators. These new KPI’s should include hub process and performance indicators with cost benefit ratios in relation to startups and jobs created through the program.
One major advantage of this proposed project is that the proposer has a great ability in using social media to the advantage of publicity of this initiative. This should be supplemented by the creation and recruitment of other required positions in a new organogram that will lead to a better implementation of this idea.
A new assessment of the problem statement and its solution will resolve a lot of the doubts associated with this project in this assessment report.

solution: Dripada will be a Cardano focused Grassroot Community Hub that will play a great role in the enlightenment and foster greater adoption of Cardano in Nigeria through meetups and learn to earn programs.
experience:
Dripada is currently a one man idea, it's the brainchild of Amaka Asouzu, an experienced web blogger who has had years of experience managing and running smaller online communities.
